title: Europe and US clash on future of Ukraine war | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Senior US officials have met with Russian president Vladimir Putin to discuss an end to the war in Ukraine. However, after nearly five hours, the Kremlin says they are no closer to a resolution. Journalist Emanuelle Chaze joins The World with her analysis. title: Indonesians blame deforestation for devastating floods | The World | ABC NEWS
description: More than 700 people have died in Sumatra, the worst-hit area of Indonesia in the recent devastating storms. Indonesians are blaming deforestation projects dating back to the 1960s, carried out by the timber and palm oil industries, and say the government has ignored the ongoing impact of forest clearing on flood mitigation. ABC Indonesia Producer Erwin Renaldi joined The World to discuss the controversy as Indonesia recovers from deadly flooding. title: Former Prince Andrew unlikely to get any money after Royal Lodge eviction | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor is unlikely to receive any compensation upon leaving Royal Lodge in Windsor, according to information published by the Public Accounts Committee. There will now be an MPs' inquiry launched into the Crown Estate and its royal leases, says committee chair, Sir Geoffrey Clifton-Brown. It's the latest development in the former Prince's fall from grace related to his ties with child sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Europe correspondent Elias Clure joined The World from London. title: EU proposes new way to support Ukraine after Putin-Witkoff talks fail | ABC NEWS
description: The European Commission is proposing to finance the Ukrainian military with frozen Russian assets as a loan after talks between Russian President Vladimir Putin showed no intention to end the Ukraine war in talks with  US Special Envoy Steve Witkoff.   Belgium, which currently hosts a large proportion of Russian funds, has expressed fears a decision to lift sanctions on Russia could expose it to litigation.  The European Commission has pledged to implement measures to prevent this scenario.  European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen says the move is sending a message to the Ukrainian people that European leaders are in it ‘for the long haul’.  Meanwhile, NATO foreign ministers have met to discuss a Ukraine peace plan but US Secretary of State Marco Rubio was noticeably absent, as fears loom that Trump withdraw from the peace process. title: Sumatra residents face fuel and food shortages after floods | ABC NEWS
description: Search and recovery operations are still ongoing a week after devastating floods and landslides devastated parts of Indonesia.  The death toll from Cyclone Senyar has risen to almost 800 while more than 450 people remain unaccounted for.  Residents in North Sumatra have shown increased frustration and anger over shortages of food and fuel as many communities are isolated and roads cut off  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-12-03/south-east-asia-flooding-hits-indonesia-north-sumatra-langkat/106093352  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Meta begins removing children's accounts ahead of social media ban | ABC NEWS
description: Meta has started to deactivate Facebook, Instagram and Threads accounts ahead of the start of the social media ban for children under 16. The US social network giant aims to purge more than half a million users before the December 10 deadline.  Ten platforms, including X and TikTok, have been targeted under the ban but the list is set to expand.  ABC national technology reporter Ange Lavoipierre says kids who both support and oppose the ban say there are ways around it. The Government itself acknowledges the system will not be 100% effective in its initial roll-out. title: Can farmers take on transmission towers and win? | ABC News Daily podcast
description: Australia’s renewable energy transition is well underway with new poles, wires and transmission towers planned across the country.   But some farmers say they’re being pressured and harassed to hand over land for the infrastructure to get electricity from where it’s generated to where it’s used.    Today, reporter Alysia Thomas-Sam from ABC’s 7.30 program on the farmers pushing back at the farm gate and climate reporter Jess Davis on why transmission towers need to run through farmland.   Featured:    Alysia Thomas-Sam, 7.30 reporter   Jess Davis, ABC climate reporter

title: Energy prices to fall by 5% over the next 5 years, watchdog forecasts | ABC NEWS
description: Household electricity prices are expected to fall by 5 per cent over the next five years due to increased renewable energy generation, according to the Australian Energy Market Commission (AEMC).  Their latest outlook suggests that more wind, solar, and battery projects will help reduce costs through 2030. However, AEMC Chair Anna Collyer warns that prices could rise if new wind projects are not developed promptly. title: Israel proposes opening Rafah crossing – but only in one direction | ABC NEWS
description: Egypt has rejected Israel's plan to reopen the Rafah border crossing with Gaza solely for Palestinians wishing to exit. Egypt says it will support the reopening of the crossing only if it allows movement in both directions. Donald Trump's peace deal included reopening the crossing in both directions to facilitate an uptick of aid for Gaza.
